title: Tuesday, 23rd January, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:03 am

Soundbuy Morning
VV75 morning
Blank canvas good morning all
BE11:03am

Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily markets live thing.

MG morning all

11:05 am
Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 1,028, up 25 (+2.49%), High: 1,040, Low: 1,015, Volume: 4.28m
BE11:06am

And it's another case where the headlines don't quite chime with the share price.

BE11:06am

UK regulator rules against Murdoch takeover of Sky

11:06 am
BE11:06am

....... yeah, but ................

BE11:06am

The CMA proposed three possible remedies that it said would address its media plurality concerns: blocking the deal outright, Fox spinning off or selling the broadcaster’s Sky News operation, or “insulating” Sky News from the “influence” of the Murdoch family.

BE11:06am

https://www.ft.com...-9650-9c0ad2d7c5b5

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Which seems to suggest a deal is more, not less, likely.

BE11:08am

And echoes the Ofcom review, so for the CMA this is simply the path of least resistance.

Grouchmonkey Morning
Mouselet Good morning assorted capitalists
BE11:08am

Here's the presser if you want it: https://www.gov.uk...he-public-interest

Mouselet exactly how do you insulate Sky News from the influence of the Murdoch family?
11:08 am
BE11:08am

And here's Polo Tang at UBS to say "buy" again, as he does most mornings.

BE11:09am

Importantly, the CMA has outlined a range of potential remedies for deal clearance including a form of ‘legal separation’ or full structural separation of Sky News, suggesting deal approval remains possible; this is positive for Sky.

Mouselet I am not sure the regulator has the ability to say 'spin off Sky News and give it an endowment sufficient to self-fund into perpetuity'
BE11:09am

The CMA was investigating two specific issues – media plurality and broadcasting standards. The CMA concluded there were no public interest issues on broadcasting standards. On media plurality, the CMA was concerned about potential influence of the Murdoch Family Trust on Sky News and the UK newspaper assets of News Corp. Both these conclusions are aligned with the Ofcom phase 1 review. Interestingly, the CMA also concluded that there would be no concerns around plurality were Sky to be ultimately acquired by Disney should the Disney/Fox deal complete

Mouselet Easyjet is soaring again
Mouselet Pets@Home up, N.Brown down
11:10 am
BE11:10am

So ........ we'll get a final decision by the first of May 2018. The fella on his horse will then rule on the issue .....

pancakes or waffles This is unrelated to the left side of this page, but perhaps (very loosely) related to the current football transfer headlines ... but the FT article on Borussia Dortmund last week was excellent
Otter Hello special internet friends I have missed you all
BE11:11am

What are the odds, incidentally, that the The Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport won't be so keen to shortcut the review process when Murdoch's involved than he has been with the bookies, incidentally?

Mouselet Good morning excellent Internet otter. May the fish be particularly tasty!
BE11:12am

He could block the deal, no matter what, but that seems rather unlikely.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Back to UBS.

BE11:13am

[I]f both Ofcom and the CMA have come to the same conclusions, it could be difficult for the UK government to block the deal. In the Ofcom phase 1 review, Fox offered a form of ‘legal separation’ as a remedy where Sky News would have a largely independent editorial board; it would retain the Sky News brand and maintain funding at similar levels for five years. In the original Fox bid for Sky in 2011, Fox was willing to completely spin off Sky News.

Otter Today I have a cinnamon bun but I have already eaten some porridge
BornCynic Morning
BE11:13am

And Citi. Also buyers.

Mouselet I have had a crunch cream biscuit and a pint of coffee for breakfast. I think wiser breakfasts exist.
11:13 am
BE11:13am

As we have consistently argued, the real risk from both the CMA and previous Ofcom investigation into public interest considerations concerned the commitment of the two companies to broadcasting standards.

BE11:13am

Had either been found to not be committed to broadcasting standard in any way, shape or form we think a deal would most likely have been prohibited outright given limited wiggle room for remedies to address this. That the CMA finds no public interest concerns around this topic is the key positive takeaway from today’s news.

BE11:14am

And ..........

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Although the headline indicates that the CMA does not find the proposed transaction to be ‘in the public interest’, it is important to note that this is very close to the same wording used by Ofcom in an earlier investigation. Indeed when we look at the CMA’s findings more broadly, they too are similar to Ofcom. The important point here is that the previous investigation found that behavioural remedies should be sufficient to give the regulator – and by extension the government – enough comfort to approve the transaction.

BE11:14am

So ...................

Peace and Love Cold chicken bananas triple espressos croissant and pain au chocolat for breakfast
BE11:15am

It strikes us that this announcement almost confirms the likelihood of the current deal getting ultimate approval from the UK government. We even see a path to full approval with no remedies – for example, an easy solution might be for Sky to sell Sky News to Disney direct in advance of the broader Fox/Disney transaction. The key question now is whether 1085p is the correct price or will a combination of regulatory approval and (maybe) a better FAPL outcome give investors a justification to push for a better price. We think Sky is worth more than 1085p on a fundamental basis (we see FV at greater than £13) so this is possible, but even with FV pegged at 1085p risk/reward looks positive.

RA i made a nice few pennies off easyjet this morning :)
Otter @Peace and love I like the sound of chicken bananasa
11:16 am
BE11:16am

Though there is an outlier among the sellside. That outlier is Liberum.

Peace and Love @Otter tastes even better than it sounds but I digress. :)
BE11:16am

The initial reaction would be to suggest there is an easy fix in that Sky News could be disposed of, either by sale or closure or some other form. However, the language of the CMA in its provisional findings suggests they are more minded to blocking the deal as a way of addressing concerns. Note the language.

“The CMA therefore takes the provisional view that prohibition of the Transaction would represent a comprehensive solution to all aspects of the provisional adverse public interest finding and that it poses relatively few risks, compared to other options, in terms of implementation or effectiveness.”

BE11:17am

The CMA does say that a remedy along the lines of what was offered in 2011 i.e. a divesture of Sky News could be appropriate. However, it does seem to suggest there would be a long list of criteria that would need to be met to be satisfied. Its language on behavioural remedies looks more sceptical.

Therefore, we think there is an increased risk that the acquisition does not go through. Given our Buy recommendation was based on the gap between the share price and the acquisition price and the probability of the deal going through, it is clear that the risks have now increased. We think there is now a 40% chance the deal does not go through. So, with the standalone DCF standing at 722p and the bid at 1075p, a weighted risk average would give a price of 930p, where we expect the shares to move towards today.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

And of course, our thoughts and prayers are with our friends at Sky News during this difficult time.

BE11:19am

See Mark Di Stefano's Twitter for a good, Inside Baseball view of what's happening there this morning: https://twitter.com/MarkDiStef

Let me get a quick results summary before moving onto the wider picture. Goldman will do.

Matt B anything on Dignity today?
Pseudonym It doesn't seem quite right that there's only one CMA.
11:26 am
BE11:26am

Outlook :
Pricing: 1Q total revenue per seat ex-FX +6.6% vs. “low to mid-single digit” guidance (consensus is unavailable)
Outlook: 2Q pricing is expected to increase in the mid-high single digits given strong prior bookings and lower market capacity growth. Easter timing will be positive for 2Q and negative for 3Q.
Costs: 1Q cost per seat ex-fuel ex-FX -1%. n
Outlook: The company expects costs ex-fuel to rise c. 1% for FY18 but costs including fuel to fall by c. 1%, in line with previous guidance
Fuel and FX: the company is 79% hedged on fuel for FY18 and expects their fuel bill to fall by £80-100 million in FY18 vs. FY17 with jet fuel at current prices. FX movements are expected to have a £5mn positive effect.
Read across for LCCs: strong pricing is positive for LCCs and Ryanair in particular who have the highest route overlap with easyjet.

Lefevre Loss of Monarch was huge help for Easyjet, flights over Xmas to places like Canaries went thru the roof
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYA:LSE): Last: 16.90, up 0.42 (+2.55%), High: 17.09, Low: 16.89, Volume: 1.30m
caustic Where is Monday's report. Can find an entry for Friday twice
BE11:27am

Though perhaps more interestingly, RBC turned positive an hour or so ahead of the numbers.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Which is hella brave.

BE11:28am

(@caustic: are you sure one of them is not Monday's that we accidentally called Friday? Because that's the kind of thing we do over here on Monday mornings.)

BE11:29am

We move easyJet to OP (from SP) with PT lifted to £17. Our rating/PT lift reflects structural changes (beyond the cycle) which as they materialise could exert upward pressure on profit prospects and our PT from:
• (1) 2018-2019 sees a growing chance major London rail infrastructure changes (Crossrail/Thameslink) will come to fruition (that we find investors have not yet considered). The now increasingly probable delivery on new Crossrail and Thameslink service expansion looks set to open up new catchment markets to easyJet at Gatwick and Luton – to the likely detriment of Heathrow’s legacy operators.
• (2) Legacy FFP devaluation favouring LCCs: We think legacy airlines' brand weaknesses will be exacerbated further by upcoming likely (effective) FFP mileage programme devaluations (e.g., BA remarks suggest a change soon) making the high-volume of potentially lower-repeat, price-focused leisure customers more LCC-focused.
• (3) Consolidation: Increased FCF prospects that we see for legacy airlines suggests increased chances of planned (vs. distress-led) industry consolidation. We think buyers will likely focus on longer-term strategic value – potentially beyond the stand-alone value we see for easyJet.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

• In addition, we see cyclical support from:
• Trading in Q1-2017/18 remains supportive – seeing a 6.6% increase in rev/seat (underlying) and likely mid-high single-digit growth for Q2. We see a likely 6-8% cons FY17/18E adj'd PBT upgrade to £470m-£480.
• Early summer 2018 seat supply indications: Even with former
distressed seats re-operated, summer 2018 supply looks constructive enough to see fares flat to up, on average.
• High fuel, weak USD constructive to Europe’s largest LCCs: We see continuing high fuel cost as constructive to airline supply and sustained profitability (beyond lagging supply, price reactions in the short term)
• (For now) easyJet’s rising debt leverage amplifies equity: In our view, its lowest in RBC-covered group FCF generation nonetheless leaves it most exposed to downside risk when the upgrade cycle peaks.

Our scenarios-based PT, based on 2018/19E delivers our £17 PT, which support our upgraded Outperform view, and implies 13.6x PER (vs. 5 year historical median 13.1x).

BE11:37am

Here's Stifel to take up the rest of the story.

BE11:38am

Exchange Translation : With 58% of profit derived from outside the UK, the recent strength of sterling is expected to depress profits by around 1.5% this year, based on current exchange rates.
Finance, Special Dividend & Consolidation : Net debt was £262m at September 2017 giving net debt : EBITDA of 1.0x. The previously announced £100m (c. 21p per share) special dividend will be payable in late April 2018 together with a share consolidation. Proforma leverage of 1.4x will remain conservative in relation to a range of 1.5-2.0x, which gives SSP scope to expand through acquisition if suitable opportunities arise, although the group has a cautious approach towards acquisitions.
We will update our forecasts once the precise details are available, but based on the current share price, we estimate the share count will reduce by 3% and EPS will increase on a proforma basis by around 2%. The shares are cum both the final dividend of 4.9p, payable in March, and a special dividend of c.21p per share payable in April.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Outlook, Forecasts :The new financial year has started well and the pipeline of contracts is encouraging. We increase our Pre Tax Profit forecast by £5m to £169m for the current year, with EPS increasing by 2% to 22.6p, with similar upgrades to future years.
Valuation : This is another encouraging update from SSP. While the group has good prospects and a driven management team, the shares have been progressively re-rates and now stand on a very demanding rating which leaves no room for disappointment. The upgrade cycle cannot continue indefinitely. We increase our price target slightly to 580p, based on 25x earnings, including accretion from the special dividend.

KS They have a good few collaborations also. But bigger transport hubs like the London train stations does help with footfall (Euston, St Pancras etc)
Grouchmonkey @flaneur twitter gossip incorrect. NOAA is an "essential service" so maintained during the fed shutdown
Otter Is there anything to say about our toilet friends at the Accrol yesterday?
BE11:39am

And Panmure ......

BE11:40am

[A]t this early stage of the year as comps toughen (Q1 revenue
growth last year of 5.4% vs. 11.7% for FY17). Whilst inherently lumpy, management is now guiding to net contract gains +4% for 2018 (including TFS India) vs. c3% before We expect any consensus upgrades to be minimal at this early stage of the financial year, given expected FX headwind of 1.5%. We currently forecast FY18 EBIT grows 8% to £176m, in line with consensus. We model 5.2% revenue growth (2.5% LFL, 1.8% net contract wins, 1.0% TFS India) and 20bp operating margin expansion to 7.0%, following 80bp in FY17 (at constant FX).

11:40 am
BE11:40am

SSP is enjoying positive earnings momentum and earning its stripes as a ‘compounder’. We forecast a total return of c.12% TSR (FY17-FY20 CAGR) coming from 7% EPS CAGR (5% revenue growth and 45bps operating margin expansion to 7.3%) and 5% dividend yield (40% ordinary pay-out and special dividends up to 1.2x ND/EBITDA leaving scope for £100m-£200m M&A within 1.5x-2.0x leverage parameters). The business is in strong shape and well placed to deliver multi-year growth given its market position in a structurally growing industry. But we lack conviction to chase the shares at this level, with future ‘beat and raise’ expectations increasingly discounted in the shares, in our view. NB headline EV/EBITDA is flattered by minority interests – adjusting for which, we estimate FY19 EV/EBITDA of greater than 14x. The FCF yield is more pedestrian at 4% and we stay at HOLD.

BE11:41am

All of which is interesting, though doesn't really move the story on much.

BE11:41am

Neither does it explain why there seems to be a bit of noise around SSP right now with regards M&A.

Crimsonadder One of old favourites Wirecard under pressure today after report from Southern Investigative Reporting Foundatioon. Just before Christmas Marcus Braun pledged 4.2 million his shares. Could this be the writing on the Wall at last.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

We have turned bullish on Croda’s ability to deliver consistently strong organic growth. In combination with the company’s admirable track record of innovation, strong returns, and scope for cash returns to shareholders we see no reason why the shares should not trade on a higher multiple, closer to that of other consumer chemicals names.

BE11:49am

Within the Personal Care segment, we think a combination of greater demand for premium products in the consumer market and a shift in Croda’s customer composition from multinationals to independent players will drive growth. This will be supported by improving growth in the company’s Life Sciences division. We also expect pricing growth to return in light of raw material inflation. Crucially, in our view, Croda will be able to maintain strong organic growth rates in the medium term, meaning the shares deserve to trade in line with consumer chemicals names such as Givaudan.

BE11:49am

Expect special dividend and further M&A: Croda has been able to manage leverage and free cash flows well throughout the cycle. On our numbers, net debt/EBITDA (excluding pensions) for 2017 should come in at 0.9x, which suggests to us that Croda will announce a special dividend at its FY 2017 results, implying a yield of 4.6% for 2017. If a special dividend is paid, we still think that further bolt-on M&A will be an option for Croda.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Stable returns, strong margins: Given our expectations for organic growth and Croda’s c50% exposure to the consumer market, we believe it makes sense to compare Croda to consumer chemicals names like Symrise and Givaudan. Croda trades on a 2018E P/E multiple of c24x, representing a 15% discount to Symrise and 10% to Givaudan. Given Croda has been able to generate superior returns compared to both companies throughout the cycle and maintain stronger margins, we would argue that this valuation disparity should not exist.

BE11:50am

That kind of thing.

BE11:55am

The disappointment for Grid is an intention to apply different cost of capital assumptions for the construction and operational phases of the project, resulting in a much lower cost of capital
than under the existing RIIO framework. Ofgem estimates the net benefit to consumers / negative impact on NG to be £100m (0.36%). This arguably overstates the impact on HPC project returns, as firstly a move towards competition has been in the works for some time and secondly Ofgem has forewarned a lowering of returns expectations in RIIO-2 anyway. However, the implications for regulated network project returns more broadly
should be considered, with expectations likely to be under pressure for NG and SSE.

11:55 am

So ...... Ofgem's flagged up a WACC over a 25-year period of between 0.60% and 1.75%, which it says is “is in line with lower rates of return recently bid by investors to operate links to windfarms under Ofgem’s Offshore Transmission Operator competitive tendering regime”.

BE11:57am

BornCynic https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/jan/23/us-stock-market-trump-tax-cuts-capital
11:57 am
BE11:57am

National Grid said in a release that they had anticipated that the consultation may include a lower range on cost of capital than RIIO-T1. However, they expressed “disappointment” with the proxy competition proposal, and “do not believe that the proposed ranges for cost of debt and cost of equity included in the consultation reflect either the actual cost of financing this project or the risk being taken for construction of this complex project.” NG also believes that Ofgem has significantly overestimated the potential consumer savings in their consultation. The company will continue to work with Ofgem in the coming weeks, but “will also consider all other options” available to them if they are not able to progress satisfactorily.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Following a tumultuous 2017 marked by earnings disappointments and contracting multiples, we see a brighter outlook for earnings growth in 2018 against a strong macro backdrop and a more favourable events calendar, but multiples remain at risk as secular challenges persist. We believe structural change will continue to drive bifurcation in growth and valuation. In this note, we address five key debates to watch in 2018 and beyond:
1) Will ad spend decouple further from the macro after the 2017 inflection?
2) Will ad dollars shift more aggressively from TV to online?
3) Will fee pressure and disintermediation intensify for Agencies – and is 2018 the year of the margin reset?
4) Media/telecom convergence – what’s next?
5) Is large-scale M&A back on the table?
As most of these questions call for nuanced answers with a range of timing and differing degrees of impact, we see greater alpha potential picking stocks within subsectors rather than the subsectors – even more so this year as returns dispersions have reached all-time lows. We prefer stocks with specific narratives (self-help; portfolio reorganisation; market repair) that can demonstrate an improving growth and returns profile.

Overall, our Economists expect global GDP growth to remain strong in 2018 at 4.1%, above consensus at 3.6% and an improvement from 3.8% in 2017. They expect this strength to be broad-based across countries and across sectors (industrials and non industrials). Within the mix, they expect DM growth to pick up slightly to 2.4% (+10 bp), mostly driven by the US (+40 bp to 2.7%) on the back of a supportive fiscal policy while Euro area is expected to slow 10 bp to 2.2%. They are more optimistic on EM growth which they expect to pick up 40 bp to 5.5% (vs. consensus 4.9%) driven by most countries (particularly India +140 bp, Russia +110 bp, Brazil +160 bp, South Africa +120 bp) with the exception of China which is expected to decelerate 30 bp to 6.5%.

On a cut to FY product gross margin guidance

12:11 pm
BE12:11pm

Quick summary from UBS .........

BE12:11pm

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Sales growth was +3.2% vs cons +3.6%, with Product +2.7% v UBSe +2.5% and cons +3.2% (tough comp of +5.9%), and Financial Services (FS) +4.6% v UBSe +5% and cons +4.5% (easy comp -0.5%). FS growth was mainly driven by interest income.
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Womenswear was weak (+0.7%) vs 9.5% in H1, with higher promotions and lower product gross margin guidance. The US recovered with sales +22%. Plans to launch Global Ship Anywhere are on track and there is a new partnership with Zalando.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: Co is comfortable with cons FY PBT of £79.2m (UBSe £78.5m). Revised gross margin guidance sees Product fall to -225bps/-250bps but FS rise sharply to +500bps/+550bps.
Net small upgrade to gross margin, slightly lower costs, with a likely offset from weaker product revenue. YE net debt c.£350m from £325-335m due to loan book growth.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A:. Relief on group PBT may be tempered by reliance on FS to achieve targets.
